comment._content: Here is Settle Junction Signal Box, one man and his dog www.youtube.com/watch?v=A8-5LYL5JSU Balbriggan Signal Box, last shift of Signalman John Collier. www.youtube.com/watch?v=W7tstDRvnXo North Wales is converting to ERTMS (European Rail Traffic Management System) www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/2011/07/18/prob...

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: That signal cabin was installed by the Great Southern Railway in 1935/6 as part of a major re-signalling scheme for the Dublin area, which included converting the old fashioned semaphore signals to then modern colour light signals. You will notice the levers in Heuston cabin are rather stumpy (and easier to use!), as  they operated the points and signals electronically, rather than fully manually. Heuston cabin was eventually closed and demolished in 2002.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Signalman John Collier in Balbriggan Signal Box was using a rag to prevent blisters on his hands. I was in a signal box in the late 1950s and was shown how to get the latch up on to the quadrant. You could then use both arms to put your back into hauling the lever. Some point rodding went for a long distance and took some moving. Mind you, I was a skinny teenager then.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/88428023@N04] 
Hi, nice photo that is of your late father. Unfortunately I can't put an exact date on it, though looking at the furniture in the signal cabin and comparing it with the NLI photo, it appears to have been taken around same time, pre 1970s at least. Your father is looking at a large electronic track diagram, which shows the aspects of the signals and train positions. This dated from the opening of the cabin in 1935, and remained in use until the very end!

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Hi Dan! Finally got a chance to search through the Irish Independent and Sunday Independent online for a time frame around the middle of March 1961 (dates on our O'Dea photos usually pretty reliable), but couldn't find any photo of your Dad. You're very welcome to come in any time and search the Indo on microfilm or online, as it'd be great if we could find the issue this photo appeared in...
